abstracts.cdata!:
The National Rural Infrastructure
            Project will improve the livelihoods of the rural population
            in Senegal, and provide access to basic infrastructure, and
            services, but the Environmental Assessment (EA) reveals the
            many constraints the country faces to sustain a long-term
            agricultural development. The report addresses, first, a)
            legal constraints, namely, the absence of regulatory
            framework regarding environmental protection, and, b)
            institutional framework, hindered by weak capacity, lack of
            technical, and scientific know-how, and the absence of
            programs to sustain development. Secondly, the EA explores
            ecological constraints, indicating vast soil, and water
            erosion, partly due to drainage malpractice, drought, and
            exhaustive livestock productivity. These adverse impacts,
            have moreover affected natural habitats, causing
            deforestation, and bio-degradation. Although the project
            will be beneficial as a result of improved sanitation, and
            hygiene, and, in the prevention of endemic diseases,
            measures to mitigate adversity, call for technical
            assistance to restore soil, and crop productivity, through
            reforestation, and rational uses of forestry resources,
            which would prevent land degradation, and, suggests
            irrigation practices, to further sustain vegetation. An
            environmental training component should enhance community
            participation, assuring agricultural, forestry, and soil
            conservation best practices, and, institutional capacity
            should be strengthened to ensure infrastructure maintenance,
            and adequate management practices.
